questions.text: What is the most common type of multifetal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common type of multifetal pregnancy is dizygotic twinning, which is always dichorionic diamniotic. 

The incidence of dizygotic twins is 80% among twins. Of the monozygotic twins, monochorionic diamniotic is the most common (13-14%).

Zygosity refers to the type of conception while chorionicity refers to the type of placentation.

Types of twin pregnancies:

  • Dizygotic: 2 ova are fertilized by 2 sperms to form 2 separate zygotes.
  • Monozygotic: Single zygote (1 ovum fertilized by 1 sperm) divides into 2.
Feature Monozygotic Dizygotic
Phenotype Identical Non-identical
Genotype Identical Non-identical
Incidence 1:250 (constant worldwide) Varies with demography
Incidence after ART Increases Increases
Perinatal complications High Low

questions.text: What is the time of division of the inner cell mass in a diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy occurs if the division of inner cell mass takes place between 4th - 8th day after fertilization.

The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below.

Monozygotic twin types Time of zygote division
Dichorionic diamniotic <72 hours
Monochorionic diamniotic (more common) 4-8 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic  8-12 days
Conjoined twins >12 days

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding multifetal pregnancies?

choices.text: Number of embryos implanted affects the risk of twinning
Isograft is done between monozygotic twins
Twins of opposite sex are usually dizygotic
Same sex twins having same blood group are always monozygotic

questions.solution:
Same sex twins of the same blood group are not always monozygotic but can also be dizygotic twins as well. The genetic relationship between dizygotic twins is the same as any siblings.

Option A: More the number of embryos transferred in IVF, more is the risk of twinning. Hence, single embryo transfer is being recommended by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (2017) to prevent twin gestation.

Option B: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins as they have HLA homology.

Option C: Twins of the opposite sex are usually dizygotic. Rarely, somatic mutations or chromosomal aberrations can change the sex of 1 or both of the monozygotic twins.

questions.text: The examination findings of a pregnant woman are suggestive of her having conjoined twins. Which is the most common type of such twins?
questions.solution:
Thoracopagus is the most common type of conjoined twins.

Division of the inner cell mass after the 12th day of fertilization results in the development of conjoined or Siamese twins. Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types:

  • Ventral
    • Rostral
      • Omphalopagus (abdomen)
      • Thoracopagus (upper chest)
      • Cephalopagus (head)
    • Caudal
      • Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angle)
    • Lateral
      • Paraphagus (side by side fusion with a shared pelvis)
  • Dorsal
    • Craniopagus (skull)
    • Rachipagus (vertebral arches)
    • Pyopagus (pelvis)

Sharing of organs is common among conjoined twins. MRI imaging is done later in pregnancy for the evaluation of organ sharing between conjoined twins who are being planned for surgical separation.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to calculate the incidence of multifetal gestation?
questions.solution:
The incidence of multiple pregnancies is calculated by Hellin’s rule.

According to this rule, incidence= 1 : 80(n-1), where n is the number of fetuses.

Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies are:

  • Monozygotic
    • ART
  • Dizygotic
    • Race
    • Heredity
    • Maternal age
    • Parity
    • Family history of twinning
    • Good nutritional status
    • Infertility therapy

Option A: Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is calculated using ventricular doppler imaging. It is used to assess cardiac function in TTTS.

Option C: CHOP score is used for cardiac evaluation of recipient twin in TTTS.

Option D: Kleihauer-Betke test is used to evaluate the approximate volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage in cases of Rh-D alloimmunization.

questions.text:
In which of the following instances is there an increased chance of twinning?
  1. 40 year old multipara with spontaneous conception
  2. Short statured and undernourished woman
  3. IVF with single embryo implanted
  4. Family history of twinning
  5. Spontaneous conception after 1 month of stopping OCP
questions.solution:
Increasing maternal age, family history of twinning, and conception after stopping OCPs increase the risk of twinning.

Taller, well-built women have an increased risk of twinning compared to shorter undernourished women. IVF increases the risk of twinning but single embryo transfer reduces the risk of multifetal pregnancies.

Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies:

  • Monozygotic
    • ART
  • Dizygotic
    • Race
    • Heredity
    • Maternal age
    • Parity
    • Family history of twinning
    • Good nutritional status
    • Infertility therapy

Note- A family history of twinning (maternal and paternal) causes an increased chance of twinning. It is seen that maternal history of twinning has a higher chance of twinning as compared to a paternal history of twinning.

questions.text: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen?

choices.text: Fertilisation of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilisation of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasion

questions.solution:
Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova released in the same cycle, by two separate acts of coitus within a short period of time.

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova in the same menstrual cycle (as suggested by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can occur even after artificial reproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. Heteropaternal superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may give rise to the doubt of adultery and infidelity. 

Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova released in different menstrual cycles. This is not seen in humans. The nidation and development of one fetus over another fetus is theoretically possible until the decidual space is obliterated by 14-16 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image?

choices.text: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
It cannot be detected by sonography
It is diagnosed usually after delivery
Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension

questions.solution:
The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed against the fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography.

In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetus continues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes:

Outcome Type
Disappears Vanishing twin
Gets compressed Fetus compressus
Flattened through desiccation Fetus papyraceus

Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin:

  • Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in the surviving twin
  • Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity in the surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses.
  • Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin
  • Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demise

Death in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. The surviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise.

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to have twins during her dating scan. What is the most common presentation in such pregnancies?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation in twins is both vertex/ cephalo-cephalic presentation (60%). The other presentations include:

  • Cephalo-Breech (20%)
  • Breech-Cephalic (10%)
  • Breech-Breech (6-10%)
  • Transverse-Transverse (Rarest)

Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin as:

Presentation of the 1st twin Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Caesarean section
Transverse Caesarean section

questions.text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is:
questions.solution:
The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is 11-14 weeks.

Twin pregnancies should ideally be dated when the crown–rump length (CRL) measurement is between 45 and 84 mm (i.e. 11 + 0 to 13 + 6 weeks of gestation).

Chorionicity should be ideally determined between 11 + 0 and 13 + 6 weeks of gestation (the earliest time to identify chorionicity is 7 weeks). This is done using the membrane thickness at the site of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. The T‐sign (in monochorionic twins) or lambda sign (in dichorionic twins) can be seen here. As the determination of chorionicity is most accurate when the amnion and chorion have not yet been fused, the first‐trimester scan in twin pregnancy is highly important.

Markers of dichorionicity include 4 layers of membranes between the twins, membrane thickness >2mm, different sex of twins, 2 different placentas, and positive twin peak sign.

Women with an uncomplicated dichorionic twin pregnancy should have a first‐trimester scan, a detailed second‐trimester scan, and scans every 4 weeks thereafter. 

Women with uncomplicated monochorionic twins should have a first‐trimester scan and then scans every 2 weeks from 16 weeks onwards. This is done in order to detect TTTS and TAPS in a timely manner. 

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the ANC clinic for the first time at 14 weeks of gestation. She complains of excessive nausea and vomiting. On examination, fundal height is midway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus. The T sign in seen on USG. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the T sign seen on USG points towards a diagnosis of monochorionic diamniotic twins.

The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the separating membrane is made up only by the two amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. This can be seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.

Symptoms of multifetal pregnancy:

  • Increased nausea and vomiting in early months
  • Palpitations and shortness of breath
  • Increased swelling of legs, varicose veins and haemorrhoids
  • Unusual rate of uterine growth
  • Excessive fetal movements

Signs of multifetal pregnancy:

  • Increased weight gain
  • Hypertension
  • Barrel shaped abdomen
  • Increased fundal height and abdominal girth
  • Multiple fetal parts
  • Palpation of 2 fetal heads 
  • FHS at different spots with FHR difference of at least 10bpm

Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy is terminated between 34-37 weeks+6 days.

The below image shows the T sign.

questions.text: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign.

In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. 

Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Single placental mass
  • Presence of intervening membrane - T sign
  • Thin intervening membrane <2mm

The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days.

Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign

Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them

Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.text: A mother with twin pregnancy underwent routine USG. Estimated fetal weights were calculated for both twins. What is the criteria to diagnose pathological discordant growth in this pregnancy?

choices.text: Difference of >25% with larger twin as index
Difference of <50% with larger twin as index
Difference of >50% with smaller twin as index
Difference of >20% with larger twin as index

questions.solution:
A difference in estimated fetal weight of >20% with larger twin as index is one of the criteria for diagnosing discordant growth.

Discordant growth is the unequal size/ weight among the fetuses in a multifetal gestation. It can be diagnosed by either of the following:

  • Estimated fetal weight difference > 20%
  • Discordance = (weight of larger twin - weight of smaller twin/weight of larger twin) x 100

Discordant growth in monochorionic twins is due to placental vascular anastomoses. In dichorionic twins, it occurs due to differences in genetic growth potential and suboptimal implantation site for one of the fetuses.

questions.text: In a woman receiving artificial reproductive therapy, the inner cell mass divides on the 7th day. Which of the following complications is not seen in the resulting multifetal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The division of the inner cell mass on the 7th day will result in monochorionic diamniotic type of twin pregnancy. Cord entanglement is seen in monoamniotic twins and not in diamniotic twins.

The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below.

Monozygotic types Time of zygote division
Dichorionic diamniotic <72 hours
Monochorionic diamniotic (more common) 4-8 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic  8-12 days
Conjoined twins >12 days

Complications in monochorionic diamniotic twins occur due to placental vascular anastomoses. They include:

  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) or acardiac twin
  • Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS)

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high fetal death rate. This is due to the following complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

questions.text: What is the most common type of placental vascular anastomoses seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies?
questions.solution:
Artery-vein anastomoses are most commonly seen in monochorionic pregnancies. 

All monochorionic placentas have anastomoses that can be:

  • Superficial artery-vein
  • Deep artery-vein
  • Artery-artery
  • Vein-vein
  • One vessel with connections to multiple arteries and veins

These anastomoses are not functional as long as the fetuses are hemodynamically balanced. When a pressure gradient develops between the fetuses, complications can occur like:

  • TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome
  • TAPS - Twin anemia polycythemia sequence
  • TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusion

The most common complication in monochorionic twins is twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Deep artery-vein anastomosis is the pathology seen in this condition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is diagnosed to have twin-twin transfusion syndrome. Which of the following statements is true regarding the recipient twin in this condition?

choices.text: It is called the stuck twin

questions.solution:
Congestive heart failure is seen in the recipient twin.

Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic diamniotic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through the anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood is taken up by the recipient twin causing imbalance in the blood volumes.

Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics
Oliguria Polyuria
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Hypotension Hypertension
Anaemia Polycythemia
Activation of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) Activation of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
Renal failure, growth restriction, pulmonary hypoplasia, contractures Congestive cardiac failure, premature rupture of membranes

 Diagnosis of TTTS depends on 2 USG criteria:

  • Monochorionic diamniotic gestation
  • Hydramnios (DVP>8cm) in one twin and oligohydramnios (DVP<2cm) in the other twin

Treatment modalities for TTTS:

  • Serial amnioreduction
  • Laser ablation of vascular placental anastomoses
  • Selective fetal termination

Note: Donor twin is called the stuck twin as the oligohydramnios limits fetal movement.

questions.text: The ultrasound findings in a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy are indicative of poly-oli syndrome. What is the pathology seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In poly - oli or polyhydramnios - oligohydramnios syndrome, the basic pathology is the presence of a deep artery-vein anastomosis.

TTTS can present as poly-oli syndrome or twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS). This is usually seen in mid-pregnancy. In this syndrome, there is decreased donor renal perfusion, causing oliguria and oligohydramnios. Because of the anastomosis, the recipient twin has increased renal perfusion and increased urine production causing polyhydramnios.

Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics
Oliguria Polyuria
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Hypotension Hypertension
Anemia Polycythemia
Renal failure Congestive cardiac failure
Growth restriction Premature rupture of membranes
Pulmonary hypoplasia Hyperbilirubinemia
Contractures

questions.text:
Ultrasound findings in a twin pregnancy are given below:
  • AFI of twin A is 26 cm
  • AFI of twin B is 4 cm
  • Urine visible in bladder of twin A
  • Urine not visible in bladder of twin B
  • Abnormal Doppler flow in twin B

What is Quintero staging in this case?
questions.solution:
The given USG findings are indicative of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) with twin A being the recipient and twin B being the donor twin. Oligohydramnios (AFI<5cm), absent urine and abnormal Doppler flow findings in the donor twin indicate stage III of twin-twin transfusion syndrome according to Quintero staging.

Quintero staging system for TTTS classification:

Stage USG findings
I Discordant amniotic fluid volumes + urine visible in donor's bladder
II Discordant amniotic fluid volumes + urine not visible in donor's bladder
III Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of umbilical artery/vein or ductus venosus
IV Ascites or frank hydrops in either twin
V Death of either twin

questions.text: An anxious mother pregnant with twins was recently diagnosed with twin-twin transfusion syndrome. She wants to know the possible fetal outcome of the pregnancy. Which of the following investigations can be used to predict this?
questions.solution:
In twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), the fetal outcome depends on the cardiac function of the recipient twin. Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is used to assess the ventricular function using doppler.

Option A: Deepest vertical pocket on USG is used to diagnose polyhydramnios-oligohydramnios in TTTS.

Options B and D: Fetal haemoglobin and MCA peak systolic velocity are used to diagnose TAPS (Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome).

questions.text: What is/are the placental vascular abnormality that can be seen in the condition depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an acardius acephalus fetus. This refers to the acardiac twin seen in twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP). Both artery-artery and vein-vein anastomosis can be seen in TRAP.

TRAP is a placental vascular anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. In this disorder, deoxygenated blood from the donor twin enters the recipient twin through the anastomosis and supplies the lower half of the recipient’s body. Hence, the heart and upper body of the recipient is poorly developed.

The below image depicts the circulation pattern seen in TRAP.

 

Based on the supply of deoxygenated blood, the recipient twin might have the following fates:

Fate Type
Lower body is perfused with failed head growth Acardius acephalus
Partially developed head with identifiable limbs Acardius myelecephalus
No recognizable structure Acardius amorphous

The donor twin develops high output cardiac failure.

The treatment for this condition is radiofrequency ablation of the acardiac or recipient twin.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, goes into labour. Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, she was taken to the OT for internal version. What could have been the possible indication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The second twin being in transverse lie is the only indication for internal version in modern obstetrics.

In a twin pregnancy, if the first twin has vertex presentation, vaginal delivery can be performed. Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, if the second twin is in transverse lie, it is corrected by external version (preferably cephalic) into a longitudinal lie. If external version fails and the membranes are intact, internal version is done under general anaesthesia, followed by breech extraction. 

If the membranes are ruptured, caesarean section is done immediately.

Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin:

Presentation of the 1st twin Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Caesarean section
Transverse Caesarean section

questions.text: Identify this condition.
questions.solution:
The given specimen depicts a monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy as:

  • 2 umbilical cords are arising from 1 placenta (monochorionic)
  • No intervening amniotic membrane is attached to the placenta. This means that both fetuses must have been inside a single amniotic cavity (monoamniotic). 

Option B: In Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, on gross examination, there will be 1 placenta and intervening 2 layers of amnion attached to the placenta. In this type of pregnancy, each fetus will have its own amniotic cavity (diamniotic) with a shared placenta (monochorionic). This is seen if the fertilized zygote divides into 2 between 4-8 days.

The below given gross image of monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy shows two umbilical cords arising separately from the placenta with the intervening amniotic membrane held by the forceps.

Option D: In dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy each fetus has it’s own amnion & chorion. The placentas here may be fused or separate. This is seen in dizygotic twins as well as monozygotic twins that divide within 0-4 days.

Option A: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)  most commonly complicates monochorionic (single placenta) twin pregnancy. In TTTS blood is transfused from the donor twin to the recipient twin through the abnormal vascular connections within the placenta leaving the donor anemic while the recipient becomes polycythemic.

The box below describes the type of amnion and chorion seen in different types of twins depending on the time of division.

Dizygotic twins Dichorionic diamniotic

Monozygotic twins- division occurs within

0-4 days

4-8 days

8-12 days

>13 days

 

Dichorionic diamniotic

Monochorionic diamniotic

Monochorionic monoamniotic

Monochorionic monoamniotic conjoined twins

questions.text: A pregnant woman was diagnosed with triplets on ultrasound. The obstetrician has planned to do a selective fetal reduction of one of the fetuses to improve the outcome of the pregnancy. What is the ideal timing and the method for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Selective fetal reduction is done between 10-13 weeks via intracardiac injection of KCl.

In multi-chorionic multifetal gestations, selective reduction of the smallest or anomalous fetus/fetuses is done to increase the chance of survival of the other fetuses. 

Laser ablation or bipolar coagulation of the umbilical cord of the targeted fetus is done. This protects the surviving fetuses from the adverse effects of the drug.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Immediate cesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation. 

Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:

Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery
Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean section

 The mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:

1st twin presentation Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Cesarean section
Transverse Cesarean section

After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in a transverse lie, the internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction.

Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech:

  • Interlocking of twins
  • Fetal head trapping above the cervix
  • Umbilical cord prolapse

According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In the case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks. According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, a Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida with dichorionic diamniotic twins presents to the clinic in active labor. The first twin is delivered vaginally but the second has a transverse lie. A trial of ECV was unsuccessful. What is not a complication of the procedure performed next for the delivery of the second twin?
questions.solution:
The given clinical procedure is suggestive of internal podalic version for the second twin. Shoulder presentation, and not face presentation, is a complication of this procedure.

The complications seen with internal podalic version are as follows: 

  • Maternal-
    • Failure of the procedure
    • Uterine rupture
    • Vaginal and perineal trauma
    • Placental abruption
    • Postpartum haemorrhage
    • Ascending infection
    • Anaesthetic risks
  • Fetal-
    • Cord prolapse
    • Shoulder presentation with prolapsed arm
    • Skeletal injury (femur, hips, humerus, skull)
    • Visceral injury (kidney, liver, spleen)
    • Neural injury (facial nerve)
    • Hypoxic brain injury
    • Death
